topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1: Mapping Backend to Volume Type

body.p: You can use the Cinder backend, create a volume type and associate it with this backend using the Horizon Overcloud dashboard, or the Cinder CLI. The following sections explains how to create a Volume Type and map it to a given backend for Cinder using the Overcloud Horizon dashboard.
The page covers the following topics:

p.xref: Associate the volume type to a backend

section.title: Before you begin
section.p: Before you start working with volume types, ensure that the following prerequisites have been fulfilled:

li.p: HPE Helion Cloud is deployed.
The cloud is created and the Cinder service is up and running.

section.title: Create volume type
section.p: To create a volume type using the Overcloud dashboard, do the following:

li.p: Log into the Overcloud Horizon dashboard. The Overcloud dashboard displays with the options in the left panel.
From the left panel, click the Admin tab and then click the Volumes tab to display the Volumes page.
Click Create Volume Type to display a dialog box.
Create Volume Type Dialog Box
Enter the name of the volume type.
Click Create Volume Type.The newly created volume displays in the Volumes page.

section.title: Extra specifications options
section.p: The following Cinder Volume Type extra-specs options enable control over the VSA storage provisioning type (thin or full) and specify protection for backend volumes:

codeblock.codeph: hplh:provisioning thin or full hplh:data_pl r-0 or r-5 or r-10-2 or r-10-3 or r-10-4 or r-6
hplh:provisioning thin hplh:data_pl r-5 volume_backend_name MyVolumeBackend

section.p: The protection level options enable different data protection configurations. Supported data protection options are:

li.p: r-0 (RAID 0) provides the best data capacity and processing performance, but offers no data protection (no fault tolerance) in the event of a failure.

r-5 (RAID 5) consists of three or more physical disk drives in an array. Stores parity data across all drives. If one drive fails, the remaining drives use the parity data to allow the array to continue to operate until the failed drive is replaced. If more than one drive fails, the array fails.
r-10-2 (RAID 10+2) stripes and mirrors data across four or more disks.
r-10-3 (RAID 10+3) stripes and mirrors data across five or more disks.
r-10-4 RAID 10+4) stripes and mirrors data across six or more disks.
r-6 (RAID 6) is based on and extends RAID5. It requires a minimum of four drives and creates multiple parity sets such that the array can function with up to two drives failing at the same time.

section.title: Associate the volume type to a backend
section.p: To map a volume type to a backend, do the following:

li.p: Log into the Overcloud Horizon dashboard. The Overcloud dashboard displays with the options in the left panel.
From the left panel, click the Admin tab and then click the Volumes tab to display the Volumes page.
Click View Extra Specs displayed against the volume type which you want to associate to the backend. The Create Volume Type Extra Specs dialog box displays.
View Extra Specs Option
Create Volume Type Extra Specs Dialog Box
In the Key box, enter volume_backend_name. This is the name of the key used to specify the storage backend when provisioning volumes of this volume type.
In the Value box, enter the name of the backend to which you want to associate the volume type. For example:FC_backend01.
Click Create to create the extra volume type specs.

section.note: Once the volume type is mapped to the backend, you can create volumes.
